tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This question requires understanding shear stress distribution in thin-walled structures and applying it to a specific geometry shown in the image. It involves multiple concepts from solid mechanics and requires a few steps of reasoning to determine the shear stress distribution.

answer_validation.reasoning: The question states that the rectangular tube is subjected to equal and opposite forces P. This indicates a pure torsion loading scenario. For a thin-walled rectangular cross-section under pure torsion, the shear stress distribution along the legs (such as AB) is constant and non-zero, as derived in the formulas below. The shear stress is zero at the center and increases linearly towards the outer surfaces, but the average value across the thickness is constant.

step_by_step: Identify the loading condition as pure torsion, based on the equal and opposite forces P acting on the rectangular tube.

Recall that for a thin-walled rectangular cross-section under pure torsion, the shear stress distribution across the thickness is linear, with zero stress at the centerline and maximum stress at the inner and outer surfaces.
The average shear stress across the thickness is constant, as the linear variation cancels out.
Therefore, the shear stress along leg AB is constant and non-zero, which matches option B.

concepts.name: Shear Stress Distribution in Rectangular Sections

Shear Stress Distribution in Rectangular: requires: Torsion Constant for Rectangular Sections
enables: Identifying Constant Shear Stress in Pure Torsion

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing the pure torsion loading condition from the given information

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: The maximum shear stress occurs at the midpoint of the longest sides of the rectangular cross-section. The shear stress is zero at the center of the cross-section and varies linearly across the thickness.

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify Torsion Loading -> Apply Shear Stress Formula -> Analyze Distribution -> Conclude Constant Shear Stress
key_insights: Pure torsion loading leads to a constant non-zero shear stress distribution
The shear stress varies linearly across the thickness but averages out to a constant value

formulas_principles.name: Torsional Shear Stress Formula
formulas_principles.conditions: For a thin-walled rectangular cross-section under pure torsion
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula for determining the shear stress distribution

formulas_principles.name: Torsion Constant for Rectangular Sections
formulas_principles.relevance: Needed to evaluate the shear stress magnitude

industry_examples: Design of aircraft wing box structures subjected to torsional loads
specific_systems: Fuselage and wing box sections of commercial airliners
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding the shear stress distribution is crucial for structural integrity analysis and fatigue life prediction of aircraft components under torsional loads.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming the shear stress varies linearly across the thickness of the rectangular section
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Lack of understanding that the shear stress distribution is parabolic, not linear, for a thin-walled rectangular cross-section under pure torsion.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Carefully review the derivation of the torsional shear stress formula and visualize the actual parabolic distribution, not a linear one.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking the shear stress is zero along the leg AB
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Incorrectly assuming that since the shear stress is zero at the center of the cross-section, it must also be zero along the leg.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Understand that the average shear stress across the thickness is constant, even though the distribution is linear from zero at the center to maximum at the surfaces.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Shear stress distribution in thin-walled rectangular sections under pure torsion
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When analyzing torsional loading on rectangular cross-sections

flashcards.front: What is the shear stress distribution in a thin-walled rectangular section under pure torsion?
flashcards.back: The shear stress is constant and non-zero across the thickness of the section. It varies linearly from zero at the centerline to maximum at the inner and outer surfaces, but the average value is constant.

flashcards.front: A thin-walled rectangular tube is subjected to equal and opposite forces P. What is the shear stress distribution along leg AB?
flashcards.back: The shear stress along leg AB is constant and non-zero, since the loading is pure torsion.

flashcards.front: Why is the shear stress not linearly distributed across the thickness of a thin-walled rectangular section under torsion?
flashcards.back: The shear stress distribution is parabolic, not linear, due to the quadratic variation of the first moment of area (Q) across the thickness.

real_world_context.application: Structural analysis of aircraft wing box sections
real_world_context.industry_example: The wing box of a commercial airliner is subjected to significant torsional loads during flight maneuvers. Understanding the constant shear stress distribution is crucial for designing the spar webs and skin panels to withstand these loads without failure.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quickly identify the loading as pure torsion, then apply the known shear stress formula for rectangular sections.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, guess option B (constant non-zero) since this is the most common case for thin-walled sections under torsion.

search_keywords: shear stress distribution thin-walled tube torsion

alternative_methods.name: Finite Element Analysis
alternative_methods.description: Using computational FEA tools to numerically model the torsional stress distribution in the rectangular tube, without relying on analytical formulas.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: FEA can capture more complex geometries and loading conditions, but requires greater computational effort and expertise compared to the analytical approach.

connections_to_other_subjects.Solid Mechanics: The torsional shear stress formula is derived from the principles of elasticity and deformation of solid bodies.

deeper_dive_topics: Warping of open cross-sections under torsion

syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: This question is well-aligned with the GATE syllabus on torsion of thin-walled sections.

rag_quality.notes: The RAG context provided excellent information on the shear stress distribution in rectangular sections under torsion, which was directly relevant to solving this question.
